comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: German diplomat. See for example, NYT of Dec 1, 1903, when he was First Secretary of the German Embassy in Washington. See also NYT of December 25, 1916 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50A16FD3E5F1373... "OFFICIAL GERMANY SPEAKS; Sympathetic to Wilson's Note, Under Secretary Bussche Says."

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: His wife:

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: This is not Baron Georg von dem Bussche-Haddenhausen (1869–1923) IMO. A photo of him and his wife is in Evening star., October 31, 1903, Page 5, see also comment under the photo of his wife. He was first secretary and counselor of the German embassy and left the USA in 1906 to be counselor of the department of foreign affairs in Berlin (Evening star., May 21, 1906, Page 5, 5. column)

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: It's Hilmar Freiherr von dem Bussche-Haddenhausen (* January 31, 1867 in Hannover; † November 19, 1939 in Ramos Mejia, Argentina) (de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilmar_von_dem_Bussche-Haddenhausen, in German) He was described as "the handsomest man In the diplomatic corps, and his wife one of the most attractive women in the same circle. ... He is the son of the late master of the horse to the Duke of Brunswick, and a member of one of the most ancient and distinguished families of Hanover." (The times dispatch., March 13, 1904, Image 19, col. 1) They had a daughter named Matilda, a photo of her is in the Amador ledger., March 23, 1906, Image 6, with description in column 1 "From the Antipodes".

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: @B-59: Agreed. According to www.wikitree.com/wiki/Von_dem_Bussche-Haddenhausen-7 Hilmar (born 1867) and Georg (born 1869) were brothers. I believe my comments/links for the "diplomat" above are in fact for Hilmar, since no first name is given.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: www.theodorerooseveltcenter.org/Research/Digital-Library/... is a letter from Herbert H. D. Peirce to Hilmar. At least the Theodore Roosevelt Center recognizes the diplomat in the US in 1903 as Hilmar.

comment.author: 35075914@N06
comment._content: Thanks, all.  We'll add "Hilmar" to the record.
